page.title: 03ORIGINS OF VILLAGES
page.content: The ancient name{PITTINGDUN}tells the story of its origin.{DUN}or{DON}is the Saxon word for{HILL}and{PITTING} denotes the{CLAN OF THE PITTS};the people who first reclaimed and occupied the land.Therefore the name Pittington really means the "hillside settlements of the Pitts." Low Pittington stands on the site of the original settlement, dated c. 624. Later a second village at Hallgarth sprang up and with it a "little town" on the spot where Littletown Farm now stands. The present villages of High Pittington and Littletown became established with the up-surge of railways and mining. To each village an estate of council houses was added after the First World War, and at the present time Priors Grange, an estate of private dwellings, is being built.
